Marsupials

Jake Hoertt and Jesus Barreto

What is a marsupial?

A Marsupial is a pouched mammal that gives birth to an undeveloped fetus.

Marsupials are structurally diverse and come in many shapes and sizes

What are some common marsupials?

What are some well known marsupials?

Kangaroos are the largest marsupial. They are native to Australia and not endangered. Female Kangaroos can be seen carrying their young, called joeys, in their pouches. Kangaroos have become an unofficial symobl of Australia. They can also be seen boxing eachother in the wild.

Known as Koala Bears, they are actually Koala marsupials. Koalas are tree-dwellers and primarily eat eucalyptus plants. They have one of the smallest brains in proportion to body weight in the animal kingdom and have an underdeveloped sense of sight. Australian folklore tells of an unusually large Koala that preys on tourists, known as a drop bear.

Platypuses are one of five species of egg-laying mammals. When first encountered, explorers believed that platypuses were a joke orchestrated by indigenous groups due to their strange appearance. Platypuses are also one of the few species of poisonous mammals, as male platypuses have a poisonous spike behind their hind legs. They are also secret agents.

Sugar gliders are winged nocturnal possums native of Australia. Sugar gliders do not have actual wings, but skin flaps similar to flying squirrels that allow them to glide through the air. Nowadays, sugar gliders are rare pets in American homes.

Where are they found?

77% of marsupial species are found in Australia

The other 33% percent of marsupials are oppossum species found in the Americas. There is only one marsupial species found north of Mexico.

via GIPHY

The American Oppossum

What are some lesser known marsupials?

The wallaby. A miniature kangaroo

The cuscus. Not the food
